pullsbody:
Bumps [knex](https://github.com/tgriesser/knex) from 0.14.6 to 0.19.5.
Changelog *Sourced from [knex's changelog](https://github.com/knex/knex/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).* > # 0.19.5 - 06 October, 2019 > > ### New features: > > - CLI: Migrations up/down commands - filename parameter [#3416](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3416) > - Oracle: Support stored procedures [#3449](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3449) > > ### Bug fixes: > > - MSSQL: Escape column ids correctly in all cases (reported by Snyk Security Research Team) [#3382](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3382) > - SQLite: Fix handling of multiline SQL in SQLite3 schema [#3411](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3411) > - Fix concurrent child transactions failing [#2213](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/2213) [#3440](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3440) > > ### Typings: > > - Add missing Migrator.list typing [#3460](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3460) > - Fix Typescript type inference for to better support wildcard (*) calls [#3444](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3444) > - Make options argument optional in timeout [#3442](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3442) > > ### Test / internal changes: > > - Enable linting in CI [#3450](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3450) > > # 0.19.4 - 09 September, 2019 > > ### New features: > > - Add undefined columns to undefined binding(s) error [#3425](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3425) > > ### Typings: > > - Add `specific` to SeederConfig type [#3429](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3429) > - Fix some issues with QueryBuilder types [#3427](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3427) > > # 0.19.3 - 25 August, 2019 > > ### Bug fixes: > > - Fix migrations for native enums to use table schema [#3307](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3307) > > ### New features: > > - Add ability to manually define schema for native enums [#3307](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3307) > - Add SSL/TLS support for Postgres connection string [#3410](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3410) > - CLI: new command that lists all migrations with status [#3390](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3390) > > ### Typings: > > - Include schemaName in EnumOptions [#3415](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3415) > - Allow `ColumnBuilder.defaultTo()` to be `null` [#3407](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3407) > ... (truncated)
Commits - [`48d8c7e`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/48d8c7eb59525df47812047f9a30e785f9883633) Prepare 0.19.5 release - [`e112a21`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/e112a21597dcfbc72877edcdd62bad2606017f12) Remove unneeded logging - [`78a7e9a`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/78a7e9aa4fe26523903f6bf726924fdc510fcb56) fix CLI tests fails caused by PR [#3416](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3416) ([#3466](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3466)) - [`988fb24`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/988fb243898d746a759d422762685a79eddf99ca) Fix MSSQL escaping ([#3382](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3382)) - [`516b074`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/516b0747901c1d3efb4097bb89f2f7bce7e7ba36) Enable linting in CI ([#3450](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3450)) - [`c1d2027`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/c1d20270d67515a83b60257dfb9139018f3f16ea) Fix handling of multiline SQL in SQLite3 schema ([#3411](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3411)) - [`53d8649`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/53d8649ef3cdbb6916ce5a2d42e9d77795f94e3b) Update test to accommodate for increased precision in PG 12 ([#3465](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3465)) - [`7fabae9`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/7fabae9f561653a5a9e31dc80844d1bc4c257e83) Migrations up/down commands: filename parameter ([#3416](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3416)) - [`fb095cb`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/fb095cb59c3f841a5833c5252d7ee7b5d3c5445d) Add missing Migrator.list typing ([#3460](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3460)) - [`b744564`](https://github.com/knex/knex/commit/b74456492c7163e02eb4353b5e44164445406519) Fix Typescript type inference for to better support wildcard (*) calls [#3444](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/3444)... - Additional commits viewable in [compare view](https://github.com/tgriesser/knex/compare/0.14.6...0.19.5)
Maintainer changes This version was pushed to npm by [kibertoad](https://www.npmjs.com/~kibertoad), a new releaser for knex since your current version.

pull_commit_message:
Gigantic UI Facelift

Everywhere:
- Restyle buttons
- Restyle / audit link styles
- Typography tweaks
- Margin/padding/sizing tweaks
- Breach card tweaks
- Start using pixels instead of rems

Landing:
- Resize forms, headlines, subheads, margins.
- Update background colors and background gradients
- Reformat "latest breach" card.
- Use SVG instead of PNG for latest breach card default logo.
- Remove hover animations in FxA sign up tout
- Change "Read More Security Tips" link to a button
- Add underline to links on hover
- Reformat breach cards

Scan Results:
- Change FxA tout to full-width banner with updated content.
- Change order of elements ("Want to scan another email?" is now before the FxA tout)
- Change "Alert me about new breaches" link at the top to a button

All breaches:
- Remove compromised accounts from breach cards
- Add aria labels to fuzzy find buttons
- Remove confusing tabindex ordering

Breach details/ "Breach Promo":
- Use single column for priority data classes
- Update FxA tout
- Tweak HIBP attribution

Dashboards:
- Change "Remove Firefox Monitor" link to button
- Show the "Remove Firefox Monitor" blurb on the Preferences dashboard

Header:
- Show zap underline on hover, or below the active link if no other "primary link" is being hovered over

Fixes most of #1167 and fixes #1220

pulltitle: Updates the call to action link in breach alerts sent to Pre-FxA subscribers.
pullsbody:
- Changes the href of the call to the action link from the user dashboard to SERVER_URL
- Changes the UTM values attached to the call to action link so that these clicks can be categorized separately.

Should fix #1278. I wasn't able to recreate the redirect to /breaches, but it does look like we were attempting to send pre-fxa subscribers to a signed in user dashboard. @groovecoder any thoughts on what could cause a redirect from the user dashboard to /breaches?

pulltitle: fix #1264: only send email to fxa if it exists
pullsbody:
I'm afraid there's another logical bug here because the code just looks at `sessionStorage.length` to see indicate the email addresses that have been scanned.

But, now that we're putting `utm_*` params into `sessionStorage` too, we need to change the logic for detecting scanned email addresses in session storage to only look at items that start with `scanned_`

pulltitle: Accepts emails on internationalized domain names
pullsbody: Since the service sends an email to verify the email address and the form already has input type `email`, using an out of date regex copy pasted from a stackoverflow answer which doesn't account for RFC822 and RFC2822 to verify email is not necessary.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Accepts emails on internationalized domain names

Since the service sends an email to verify the email address and the form already has input type `email`, using an out of date regex copy pasted from a stackoverflow answer which doesn't account for RFC822 and RFC2822 to verify email is not necessary.

pullsbody:
This starts the "Change password" flow using hard-coded password change links for the top 10 biggest/most-visited breaches on the site. We still need to:

* Implement the real UI (needs UI mock-ups from @changecourse)
* Add GA metrics pings to record how many people actually use these links

Note: this falls back to using the website domain for all the breaches outside the "top 10". Can we think of a way to measure the effectiveness of generic links vs. specific links?

pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody: ### Relevant Context & Vocabulary **Bento** (pictured above) - Hereinafter "bento" means a button that you can press to reveal (in our case) a menu of Firefox apps and services. You may also have heard this referred to as "Dandelion" because it promotes cross-pollination. The idea is that Monitor with implement The Bento by Skyline and that eventually The Bento might move to its own repository (and maybe server) where other Firefox product pages (tbd) can easily adopt it. **This PR...** adds the necessary Bento files and rearranges existing header elements to accommodate The Bento and match the spec. `fx-bento.js` looks for the `` custom element then builds The Bento items from there using localized strings fetched from `/getBentoStrings` endpoint and sprites from `/img/fx-bento-sprites.png`. The l10n fetch may be overkill if other product pages want to do their own thing with localization instead of fetching localized strings. The `._currentSite` is determined by a data attribute -`document.body.dataset.bentoAppId`- which stores the site's Bento ID (will require future organization between Bento maintainers and any consuming website). The current site's link should appear at the top of the link list inside The Bento. On small screens The Bento menu should span the full height and width of the screen and a round purple button with an "X" in it should appear in the upper right hand corner. This button should close The Bento menu when clicked. There is also an invisible pseudo element - `.fx-bento-mobile-close::after`- which should span the upper-most portion of the mobile Bento menu and also close The Bento menu when clicked. #### To be thought about now and figured out later: We may need to figure out a unified metrics system (not Amplitude, too expensive) for measuring basic operational Bento data across all the websites on which The Bento maintains a residence. The other option is that each Bento-consuming website can implement their own analytics (Send and FxA don't use GA) but that means more work for all involved and more time spent hunting down data).
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

There is also an invisible pseudo element - `.fx-bento-mobile-close::after`- which should span the upper-most portion of the mobile Bento menu and also close The Bento menu when clicked. #### To be thought about now and figured out later: We may need to figure out a unified metrics system (not Amplitude, too expensive) for measuring basic operational Bento data across all the websites on which The Bento maintains a residence. The other option is that each Bento-consuming website can implement their own analytics (Send and FxA don't use GA) but that means more work for all involved and more time spent hunting down data).
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Bug fixes

- Enables arrow navigation through bento links.
- Prevents bento menu from getting scrolled away on mobile.
- Resizes bento height if necessary on bento opens and window resizes when `window.innerHeight` is less than 500px.
- Enables bento scrolling
- Fixes UTMs
- Updates Lockwise link (still waiting on new Lockwise domain to go live).

pullsbody: ### Relevant Context & Vocabulary **Bento** (pictured above) - Hereinafter "bento" means a button that you can press to reveal (in our case) a menu of Firefox apps and services. You may also have heard this referred to as "Dandelion" because it promotes cross-pollination. The idea is that Monitor with implement The Bento by Skyline and that eventually The Bento might move to its own repository (and maybe server) where other Firefox product pages (tbd) can easily adopt it. **This PR...** adds the necessary Bento files and rearranges existing header elements to accommodate The Bento and match the spec. `fx-bento.js` looks for the `` custom element then builds The Bento items from there using localized strings fetched from `/getBentoStrings` endpoint and sprites from `/img/fx-bento-sprites.png`. The l10n fetch may be overkill if other product pages want to do their own thing with localization instead of fetching localized strings. The `._currentSite` is determined by a data attribute -`document.body.dataset.bentoAppId`- which stores the site's Bento ID (will require future organization between Bento maintainers and any consuming website). The current site's link should appear at the top of the link list inside The Bento. On small screens The Bento menu should span the full height and width of the screen and a round purple button with an "X" in it should appear in the upper right hand corner. This button should close The Bento menu when clicked. There is also an invisible pseudo element - `.fx-bento-mobile-close::after`- which should span the upper-most portion of the mobile Bento menu and also close The Bento menu when clicked. #### To be thought about now and figured out later: We may need to figure out a unified metrics system (not Amplitude, too expensive) for measuring basic operational Bento data across all the websites on which The Bento maintains a residence. The other option is that each Bento-consuming website can implement their own analytics (Send and FxA don't use GA) but that means more work for all involved and more time spent hunting down data).

pulltitle: fix #1084 fix #1146 - only put ids and emails into user object
pullsbody:
When a user adds many email addresses, joining all of their full
email_addresses records data into the session user object makes the
client-sessions object larger than the cookie size limit of Firefox.

This temporary fix joins only the ids and emails of the records, because
they are the only columns we're using. This cuts the object size down by
approx. 70%.

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/1148 tracks moving
session data to the back-end.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
Bumps [lodash](https://github.com/lodash/lodash) from 4.17.11 to 4.17.13.
Commits - [`e371828`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/e37182845f16715a0d1c391c8662d83c55609cee) Bump to v4.17.13. - [`357e899`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/357e899e685872b4af5403ecc4b2a928f961ae63) Rebuild lodash and docs. - [`fd9a062`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/fd9a062d57646450b61f74029315abd4cc834b08) Bump to v4.17.12. - [`e77d681`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/e77d68121ff00ba86b53eed5893d35adfe94c9dd) Rebuild lodash and docs. - [`629d186`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/629d1865793182cd967196716f4beff223aa4a91) Update OpenJS references. - [`2406eac`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/2406eac542b2a1282be8d812a6d8a45433ade80a) Fix minified build. - [`17a34bc`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/17a34bc5854bb982ef333bfe7ae469f4dfcee0ec) Fix test bootstrap for core build. - [`53838a3`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/53838a38f8e4f6204ef2f837fecc4e07d09afe77) Fix tests in older browsers. - [`29e2584`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/29e258497b5ff45494a85cfa58743517aaeeff52) Fix style:test lint nits. - [`8f4d3eb`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/8f4d3eb018884d96eb57fba3f724bfff494df724) Update deps. - Additional commits viewable in [compare view](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/compare/4.17.11...4.17.13)

pullsbody:
#### Broad strokes:
- Loads `all-breaches.min.js` separately (and without the `defer` attribute).
- Reduces the size of the breach array sent to the template by removing more unused `breachCard` properties and sending the localized `breachCard` strings once as`LocalizedBreachCardStrings`.
- Builds only the first 15 breaches on page load with a "Show All" button to see the rest.

#### `breachCard` updates:
- Renames the artist formerly known as `breachCard.String` to `breachCard.LocalizedBreachCardStrings` to match the `/breaches` breach cards. 
- Stops assigning `breachCard.Category` since we aren't doing anything with the category in the cards now anyway.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Faster loading /breaches page.

Breaches page:
- Reduces the size of the breach array sent to the template by removing more unused properties and sending the localized breach key strings once as a separate `LocalizedBreachCardStrings` object instead of with each breach.
- Builds only the first 15 breaches on page load with a "Show All" button to see the rest.

For breachCards everywhere else:
- Renames the artist formerly known as `breachCard.String` to `breachCard.LocalizedBreachCardStrings` to match the `/breaches` breach cards.

For breachCards everywhere:
- Stops assigning `breachCard.Category` since we aren't doing anything with the category in the cards now anyway.

pulltitle: fix #1044: ensure session user always has email_addresses
pullsbody: #1044 happened because some objects assigned to `req.sesion.user =` were the return of functions that did not join the `subscribers` table with the `email_addresses` table. This code updates the `requireSessionUser` call to always join the `email_addresses` records onto the user object.

pulltitle: fix #992: destroy access and refresh tokens on Remove
pullsbody:
This could be a fast-follow after release if we think it's too risky to land before. This code:

1. Adds a db column to hold the FxA access token in addition to the refresh token
2. Updates the OAuth code to store the access token it receives from FxA
3. Updates the OAuth code to update existing subscribers' FxA data every time they sign in (to get existing subscribers' access tokens, and this should help update their avatar images too.)
4. During `removeFxm` calls FxA `/destroy` endpoint for both the access token and the refresh token
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message: fix #992: destroy access and refresh tokens on Remove

pulltitle: fix #992: destroy access and refresh tokens on Remove
pullsbody:
This could be a fast-follow after release if we think it's too risky to land before. This code:

1. Adds a db column to hold the FxA access token in addition to the refresh token
2. Updates the OAuth code to store the access token it receives from FxA
3. Updates the OAuth code to update existing subscribers' FxA data every time they sign in (to get existing subscribers' access tokens, and this should help update their avatar images too.)
4. During `removeFxm` calls FxA `/destroy` endpoint for both the access token and the refresh token

pulltitle: Use `IntersectionObserver` for lazy loading breach images.
pullsbody:
- Uses `IntersectionObserver` to lazy load breach images on `/breaches`.
- Adds `IntersectionObserver` polyfill for older browser versions, Opera, and all but the very latest version of Safari.
- Loads polyfill into top-level pages (`/breaches` and `/security-tips`). We'll need IntersectionObserver for the fast-follow redesigned Security Tips page.
- Removes some old, unused, or unnecessary CSS from `all-breaches.css` and fixes an indentation nit in `all-breaches.hbs`.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
I couldn't catch this until https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/982 landed on https://fx-breach-alerts.herokuapp.com/ where we have pre-FxA subscribers.

I dug up one of those old pre-FxA subscriber emails and clicked its "unsubscribe" link. It incorrectly tried to redirect to `/users/preferences`.

So I updated a localhost user to match that old pre-FxA record and updated the `getUnsubscribe` code to fix that.

pullsbody:
@flodolo We have a number of string edits and a few new strings. We unanimously agree that we owe you champagne at Whistler.

Question:
       This string: 
      `see-if-youve-been-part = See if you’ve been part of an online data breach.`

      Is very close to these strings:
      `see-if-breached = See if you’ve been in an online data breach.`
      `scan-label = See if you’ve been involved in a data breach.`

Could we update one of the old strings and avoid creating a new string ID for this?

pullsbody:
Fixes #852


As of January 1 2019, Mozilla requires that all GitHub projects include this [CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md](https://github.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) file in the project root. The file has two parts:

1. Required Text - All text under the headings *Community Participation Guidelines and How to Report*, are required, and should not be altered.
2. Optional Text - The Project Specific Etiquette heading provides a space to speak more specifically about ways people can work effectively and inclusively together. Some examples of those can be found on the [Firefox Debugger](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) project, and [Common Voice](https://github.com/mozilla/voice-web/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). (The optional part is commented out in the [raw template file](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), and will not be visible until you modify and uncomment that part.)

If you have any questions about this file, or Code of Conduct policies and procedures, please see [Mozilla-GitHub-Standards](https://wiki.mozilla.org/GitHub/Repository_Requirements) or email Mozilla-GitHub-Standards+CoC@mozilla.com.

_(Message COC002)_

pulltitle: Fix top of funnel FxA pings.
pullsbody:
- Moves the `let fxaUrl` assignment into the following `.forEach` loop. The current implementation repeatedly appends the `entrypoint` param and results in only the first request firing correctly.

- Also cleans out some punctation muckying up the `default_dataset` helper.

To test locally, use PORT 8000 and make sure FXA_SETTINGS_URL is set to `https://stable.dev.lcip.org`
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Fix top of funnel FxA pings.

Moves the `let fxaUrl` assignment into the following `.forEach` loop. The current implementation repeatedly appends the `entrypoint` param and results in only the first request firing correctly.

- Also cleans out some punctation muckying up the `default_dataset` helper.

To test locally, use PORT 8000 and make sure FXA_SETTINGS_URL is set to `https://stable.dev.lcip.org`

pulltitle: Implement a script to add breaches missing from Remote Settings.
pullsbody:
This is my script to diff the breaches in the fxmonitor-breaches Remote Settings collection against HIBP's breach list, and add the missing ones.

I modified my script to use `got` which is already a dependency in this repo.

The post request to actually add records is untested at the moment after converting from `request-promise` to `got`.

This needs to be updated to use credentials from the environment instead of a pasted bearer token.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
- Sends "top of funnel" pings to FxA `/metrics-flow` on page load for each FxA entrypoint (Sign In button in header, Sign Up button, Sign in Link, etc). 
- Stores `flowId` and `flowBeginTime` for each entrypoint element in that element's dataset.
- When a user clicks on a given entrypoint, the `entrypoint`, `flowId`, and `flowBeginTime` values are picked out and bundled up with `utm_source` and `utm_campaign` before being sent off to the /oauth flow.

Fixes #711 
Fixes #819 
Fixes #807

pullsbody: -Fixes #806 Updates the `fluentNestedBold` helper so that it doesn't incorrectly overwrite `{ $userEmail }` and `{ $breachName }`. Now, `fluentNestedBold`: - Makes copy of `args.hash` - Sets any non-`breachCount` value in args.hash equal to its key. "000webhost" would become "breachName", for instance. - Grabs translated string with correct `breachCount` value and any other placeholder args. - Checks returned strings for the `breachCount` numeral (looks for digit(s) surrounded by whitespace) and adds markup. - Replaces placeholder vars with saved values, adds markup, and sends to template. To check this, I created a new mailinator account (123monitor_testing_number_1-@mailinator.com) and gave myself some breaches locally.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

"000webhost" would become "breachName", for instance. - Grabs translated string with correct `breachCount` value and any other placeholder args. - Checks returned strings for the `breachCount` numeral (looks for digit(s) surrounded by whitespace) and adds markup. - Replaces placeholder vars with saved values, adds markup, and sends to template. To check this, I created a new mailinator account (123monitor_testing_number_1-@mailinator.com) and gave myself some breaches locally.

pulltitle: fix #799: Add markup to { $breachCount } after grabbing localized strings.
pullsbody: This grabs the localized copy before wrapping `{$ breachCount }` in ``. Fluent doesn't interpret `{ $breachCount }` when it's wrapped in markup and the default `*[other]` string is currently being returned no matter the actual `{ $breachCount }`.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message: Add markup to { $breachCount } after grabbing localized strings. This grabs the localized copy before wrapping `{$ breachCount }` in ``. Fluent doesn't interpret `{ $breachCount }` when it's wrapped in markup and the default `*[other]` string is currently being returned no matter the actual `{ $breachCount }`.

pulltitle: Consolidate scan result logic for easier current/future templating.
pullsbody:
- Moves scan logic that was living in various/multiple controllers into standalone `scan-results.js` that returns one big object for sending to the templates.
- Updates templates with new/renamed vars.
   - `latestBreaches` is now `userDash`
   - `authenticatedUser` is now `selfScan`
   - `featuredBreach` is now `specificBreach`  (in `scan-results.js` and various result partials)
- Fixes some logic in the templates unearthed while working on this. Specifically:
   - Single breach results not showing up on `fullReport` and `userDash` pages.
   - Some incorrect response headlines/subheads when signed in users scan emails other than their own from featured breach pages.
   - Fixes rder and appearance of the sign up banner, the download banner, and the what to do tips on result pages.
   - See Full Report incorrectly showing up when a signed in user scans an email that is not their own from a featured breach page.
- Sets us up to move all of the iffing/elsing/unlessing/ifComparing out of the handlebars templates and into something a bit easier to wrangle.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message: Add scan-results.js and update controllers and routes.

pulltitle: start FxA fixes for new templates
pullsbody:
We still need to ...

* [x] Change our OAuth client to request `profile` scope and not just `profile:email` (needs FxA team to approve)
  * [x] Store the full `profile` JSON in our DB
* [x] Include `access_type=offline` in our query params to get a long-life refresh token
  * [x] Store the refresh token in our DB

pull_commit_message: for #669: check db array and catch basket error

pullsbody:
Please update to the newest version of `fluent`. It supports the new features of the Fluent Syntax, introduced in [versions 0.7 and 0.8](https://github.com/projectfluent/fluent/releases) of the spec. The `fluent` package on npm is [versioned independently](https://github.com/projectfluent/fluent.js/blob/master/fluent/CHANGELOG.md) of the spec versions, but the gist is that `fluent` 0.10 supports the most recent syntax spec.

This is important to us because we'd like to roll out the support for these new features in Pontoon soon. Once available, localizers will be free to use them in their translations. I'd like to make sure `blurts-server` is ready for any such updated translations.

I tested this locally briefly, i.e. without creating a DB nor connecting to HIBP. The landing page and some error pages showed up localized as expected. Thanks!
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
Please update to the newest version of `fluent`. It supports the new features of the Fluent Syntax, introduced in [versions 0.7 and 0.8](https://github.com/projectfluent/fluent/releases) of the spec. The `fluent` package on npm is [versioned independently](https://github.com/projectfluent/fluent.js/blob/master/fluent/CHANGELOG.md) of the spec versions, but the gist is that `fluent` 0.10 supports the most recent syntax spec.

This is important to us because we'd like to roll out the support for these new features in Pontoon soon. Once available, localizers will be free to use them in their translations. I'd like to make sure `blurts-server` is ready for any such updated translations.

I tested this locally briefly, i.e. without creating a DB nor connecting to HIBP. The landing page and some error pages showed up localized as expected. Thanks!

pulltitle: Additional breach filtering / Hide non-website breaches everywhere.
pullsbody:
There was a lot of confusion about the "You've Been Scraped" breach alert we sent out on 12/6. Earlier today a decision was made to hide non-website breaches until new content has been created to explain them.
This hides breaches in website scan results, email reports, and prevents the sending of new breach alerts when  `breach.IsFabricated`, `breach.IsSpamList`, and when `breach.Domain === ""`.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Add temporary filters to website email scans, email reports, and new breach alerts.

There was a lot of confusion about the "You've Been Scraped" breach alert we sent out on 12/6. Earlier today a decision was made to hide non-website breaches until new content has been created to explain them.  This hides breaches in website scan results, email reports, and prevents the sending of new breach alerts when  `breach.IsFabricated`, `breach.IsSpamList`, and when `breach.Domain === ""`.

pull_commit_message:
Update/condense breach filtering and add res.status(200)

- Filters unverified breaches back out of all results
- Condenses `HIBP.getUnsafeBreachesForEmail` and `HIBP.getBreachesForEmail`
- Adds res.status(200) to response when we receive a breach for which we will not be sending alerts

pulltitle: Additional breach filtering / Hide non-website breaches everywhere.
pullsbody:
There was a lot of confusion about the "You've Been Scraped" breach alert we sent out on 12/6. Earlier today a decision was made to hide non-website breaches until new content has been created to explain them.
This hides breaches in website scan results, email reports, and prevents the sending of new breach alerts when  `breach.IsFabricated`, `breach.IsSpamList`, and when `breach.Domain === ""`.

pulltitle: Add Email.png and List.png logos for non-website breaches
pullsbody:
Should fix the missing logos on the following breaches:

```sh
$ curl https://monitor.firefox.com/hibp/breaches | jq '[. [] | select(.LogoPath|test("(Email|List).png")) | {Name:.Name, LogoPath: .LogoPath}]'

[
  { "Name": "2844Breaches",            "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "AntiPublic",              "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "B2BUSABusinesses",        "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "DataAndLeads",            "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "DataEnrichment",          "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "Digimon",                 "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "ElasticsearchSalesLeads", "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "ExploitIn",               "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "VINs",                    "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "KayoMoe",                 "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "OnlinerSpambot",          "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "Pemiblanc",               "LogoPath": "List.png" },
  { "Name": "RiverCityMedia",          "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "SaverSpy",                "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "SCDailyPhoneSpamList",    "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "SpecialKSpamList",        "LogoPath": "Email.png" },
  { "Name": "TrikSpamBotnet",          "LogoPath": "Email.png" }
]
```

Fixes #653
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
The confirmation, unsubscribe, unsubscribe survey, and error pages now all use the same layout (since the confirmation page redesign). This creates a single view for all of these pages, uses partials for page specific elements, and updates the confirmation page to the new spec. Routes updated where necessary.

New to the confirmation page:
- Option added for the user to share a link to Firefox Monitor by email, with options for opening the prepopulated email in the user's default mail client or in Gmail, Yahoo, or Outlook email web apps.
- GA pings sent for each of these on click

Fixes #628

pullsbody:
- Replaces scan form on sensitive featured breach pages with a "Get Your Report" button. Currently if a user lands on a sensitive featured breach page (/?breach=AshleyMadison, for example) and scans their email address they will be told that their email address was not compromised in that breach regardless of whether or not it actually was compromised since we are not showing sensitive breach results to the public via the website.

- Removes the "Get Your Report" button in the sign up banner on sensitive featured breach pages and expands the blurb about Firefox Monitor reports.

pullsbody:
CODEOWNERS will ping me for review whenever FTL files in /en are changed

l10n.toml can be used for automation, i.e. install `compare-locales` 

```
pip install compare-locales
```

Then run from the root

```
compare-locales l10n.toml . it
```

You can also get JSON and use it for automation (level of completion, errors).

- No more purple backgrounds throughout. Restyles emails so that they're more likely to remain legible in the face of email client quirks.
- A more better button.
- Adds Fira Sans for those clients that observe these things.
- Prevents main content area from spanning the entire width of the email in Outlook. 
- Adds copy to verification email (still waiting on What To Do blurbs for breach reports).

pullsbody:
- Creates SVG sprite sheet for flat icons.
- Creates PNG sprite sheet for gradient filled icons that could not reliably be called from SVG sprite sheet on all browsers (specifically Safari).
- Replaces inline images with CSS background-images, background-image PNG sprites or SVG sprites.
- Adds aria labeling to sprite-wrapping links without text.

Brings image requests, excluding google analytics, down to 5 and reduces total KB transferred. 
Fixes #315 - Flash of alt text when Firefox Monitor is reloaded.

pulltitle: start saving signup language for future emails
pullsbody:
So we can send the right translated emails to subscribers, we need to start saving their `Accept-Language` value when they sign up.

We should merge and deploy this ASAP - the longer we run without this, the more users are going to have to set their language later. 😢

pulltitle: Add pings to all the things.
pullsbody:
Fixes #440 

**Adds new folder / 3 new partials**
- Adds analytics partials folder and moves utm_site_footer into it. 
- Adds three analytics-specific partials (download_event, link_event, social_event)


**Adds Pings When Users:**
- Submit their email
- Click “Resend Confirmation Email”
- Close sign up modal before signing up (by button or by clicking outside modal)
- Close sign up modal after signing up (by button or by clicking outside modal)
- Click Terms & Privacy from modal
- Click Download Firefox link from top bar
- Click Download Firefox from page banner
- Click Download Firefox from footer
- Click "Unsubscribe" button
- Click "Show More [additional breaches]" button
- Click any link in footer
- Click HIBP link
- Hit an error or confirmation page

Also restructures some pings we were already sending to align with analytics team's request.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message: Add pings to all the things.

pullsbody:
Previously, the `hibp` module code caught and logged errors but didn't throw them up to calling code.

This meant that, for example, a `kAnonReq` scan that encountered an error connecting to HIBP (as we saw when our load test was throttled by Cloudflare) returned an `undefined` response, which was taken by the calling code to mean 0 breach results!

This PR:

* Introduces `HIBP._throttledGot` which adds a configurable throttle on HIBP requests to help respect throttled responses
* Throws HIBP connection errors up to calling code with a friendly message: "Error connecting to HIBP."
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pulltitle: DNM yet: Handle unsubscribe flow refreshes/unsub form resubmits
pullsbody:
- Moves unsubscribe survey into separate template
- Allows user to refresh unanswered survey form without being redirected to ("/");
- Prevents multiple survey form submissions
- Throws "this email is not subscribed to Firefox Monitor" error when answered unsubscribe survey form page is refreshed (maybe it makes more sense to redirect to landing page?)

- Allows user to refresh an unsubmitted survey form without being redirected to ("/");

- Throws "this email is not subscribed to Firefox Monitor" error when users refresh the unsubscribe survey page after submitting an answer.

pulltitle: consolidate on express-handlebars for web + email
pullsbody:
Web templates were using express-hbs while email templates used
express-handlebars. Change both to use express-handlebars, which also
lets us share helpers between email + web templates.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
consolidate on express-handlebars for web + email

Web templates were using express-hbs while email templates used
express-handlebars. Change both to use express-handlebars, which also
lets us share helpers between email + web templates.

pulltitle: fix #270 fix #245: serve breach data to clients
pullsbody:
Client may send a GET request to `/hibp/breaches` with `If-Modified-Since` header value of its most recent breach DateTime.

If the server has a breach that is newer than the client's `If-Modified-Since` value, it will respond with the full breach JSON data and a new `Last-Modified` value for the client to store. Otherwise, it will respond with an empty `304` response.

After sending the response to the client, the server checks to see if it has loaded upstream breach data from HIBP within the last `HIBP_RELOAD_BREACHES_TIMER` milliseconds (Default 60000 or 10 min.). If not, it reloads upstream breach data and sets the appropriate state for `If-Modified-Since` checks and `Last-Modified` values.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

fix #270 fix #245: serve breach data to clients

pulltitle: Use Title instead of Name for breach
pullsbody:
Now, the only place `{{ Name }}` is used is in `` attributes and an `` and nothing user facing. ```sh $ git grep "Name }}" views/partials/breach_listing.hbs: views/partials/featured_breach.hbs: views/partials/scan_form.hbs: ``` ```sh $ git grep "Title }}" views/email/breach_notification.hbs: Uh-oh, {{ email }} was involved in {{ breach.Title }} data breach. views/monitor.hbs:

See if your account was exposed in the {{ featuredBreach.Title }} breach or other data breaches.

views/partials/breach_listing.hbs: views/partials/breach_listing.hbs:

{{ Title }}

views/partials/featured_breach.hbs: views/partials/featured_breach.hbs: {{ featuredBreach.Title }} views/partials/featured_compromised_account_headline.hbs: The account you scanned was compromised in the {{ featuredBreach.Title }} breach. views/partials/featured_compromised_account_headline.hbs: Your account wasn't compromised in the {{ featuredBreach.Title }} breach. ```
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
WIP / Needs cleaning - What do we think of getting the breaches by domain ("/?breach=siteDomain.com") instead of by Name? This will set us up for better future handling of sites with multiple breaches and help get the branch_variants PR one step closer to merged (site.Title just needs to be site.Domain in Add-on). We can figure out what to do with the additional breaches later. 

- The 'Example Breach' I had created to replace the All Music breach is commented out right now because it started giving grief after the database reorganization. Will return to it after knocking out some Add-on things. 

Fixes #215

pull_commit_message:
sites with multiple breaches

Addressing sites with multiple breaches + resolving a lingering issue in the Add-on PR:

-adds "domain" column in database so we can grab all breaches for a given site by domain. Since we aren't currently set up to display multiple breaches, it hangs on to the first returned breach and creates a placeholder variable for the subsequent breaches that can just be deleted for now / forever / whatever. Even if we decide to not show multiple breaches, we can at least query them like this and then decide which one we want to show. Let me know what you guys think about this. I like it better than querying by name and hoping we get the most recent, most relevant breach.

pullsbody: So basically, Docker has no Git (npm ERR! code ENOGIT === Ain'tNoGit). The options are to imbue Docker with Git (which has its own set of potential issues) or to move dnt-helper.js into a vendor folder and be done with it (for now). Less elegant, but less grief for the time-being.
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Circle Appeasement

So basically, Docker has no Git (ENOGIT === Ain'tNoGit). The options are to imbue Docker with Git (which has its own set of potential issues) or to move dnt-helper.js into a vendor folder and be done with it (for now). Less elegant, but less grief for the time-being.

pullsbody:
hey guys, apologies in advance because I know it's All Hands and this is a bunch to look over!  

Bigger Things: 
- Added 'tracking-projections.js' that checks for user privacy settings and installs google analytics if tracking protection is not enabled.
- Added google analytics event handlers in 'monitor.js' (these could/maybe should be moved into their own file?).
- Modified helmet settings to accommodate google analytics.

Little(r) Things:
- Condensed Sign up button partials (button and text are no longer repeated).
- Minified Mozilla logo
- Moved false door html into it's own partial and out of monitor.js
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
This is an indication to ZAP (and potentially other security tools) that an anti CSRF token has deliberately not been added to this form.
An attacker will be able to submit an email address on behalf of the user but it wont cause any problems for anyone.
The data-no-csrf attribute doesnt make this any more secure, but it does allow us to ignore it and therefore not report this as a potential problem.
This should help the server pass the baseline scan as referenced in #55
pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.
pull_commit_message:
Add data-no-csrf attribute

This is an indication to ZAP (and potentially other security tools) that an anti CSRF token has deliberately not been added.
An attacker will be able to submit an email address on behalf of the user but it wont cause any problems for anyone.
The data-no-csrf attribute doesnt make this any more secure, but it does allow us to ignore it and therefore not report this as a potential problem.

pullsbody:
Still `TODO`:
* [x] Figure out why the script hangs and doesn't return
* [ ] Style the HTML emails
* [ ] Inline the Foundation CSS used in the emails
* [x] Mark the subscriber/email_hash as being notified after we send them an email, to prevent double-sending

To try it out:
```
node tests/fixtures/make-breach-with-emails.js some-other@email.com
```
should add `some-other@email.com` as an email in all the breaches.

```
node scripts/notify-subscribers-of-breach.js "Test Breach 1"
```
should `console.log` all of the subscribers involved in `Test Breach 1`

Still `TODO`:
* [x] Figure out why the script hangs and doesn't return
* [ ] Style the HTML emails
* [ ] Inline the Foundation CSS used in the emails
* [x] Mark the subscriber/email_hash as being notified after we send them an email, to prevent double-sending

To try it out:
```
node tests/fixtures/make-breach-with-emails.js some-other@email.com
```
should add `some-other@email.com` as an email in all the breaches.

```
node scripts/notify-subscribers-of-breach.js "Test Breach 1"
```
should `console.log` all of the subscribers involved in `Test Breach 1`

pullsbody:
This actually enables the "Subscribe with Email Account" button, and puts the user onto a verification page when they click it.

Note: you need to unset `DEBUG_DUMMY_SMTP` and working `SMTP_*` environment variables for the email verification to actually send. https://fx-breach-alerts.herokuapp.com/ is set up with a demo account of Mailgun that is only authorized to send emails to lcrouch at mozilla dot com and nhnt11 at gmail dot com.

pulltitle: Adapt db models to allow quick scanning of breaches for a given email address
pullsbody:
This took forever and ended up being a relatively small PR. I had trouble understanding what Sequelize was doing under the hood with associations and battled several weird exceptions (one of which turned out to be a Promise race that was my fault 😢 ).

I'm going to try and push a few more commits on top of this to use this for the /scan API, and try and fix CI failure.

pullsbody:
This builds on top of #67 and #70 and is mainly meant to show how the rest of the code will start to look when we use Sequelize everywhere.

Pay most attention to the last https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/71/commits/51b3d567d442e22a43dc3aefd8e2cf9803ffe8cc commit to see the main refactorings:

* Moves user email validation "up" into the model object using Sequelize built-in validation code
* Moves the verification token into a field on the User model/table with default value generation, so we don't need an extra table
* Removes almost all of the DB "plumbing" code from `routes/users.js` since that is handled by Sequelize

If this looks good, I'll build on top of this to convert all the code to Sequelize. (Including tests)

pullsbody:
This builds on top of #67 and #70 and is mainly meant to show how the rest of the code will start to look when we use Sequelize everywhere.

Pay most attention to the last https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/71/commits/51b3d567d442e22a43dc3aefd8e2cf9803ffe8cc commit to see the main refactorings:

* Moves user email validation "up" into the model object using Sequelize built-in validation code
* Moves the verification token into a field on the User model/table with default value generation, so we don't need an extra table
* Removes almost all of the DB "plumbing" code from `routes/users.js` since that is handled by Sequelize

If this looks good, I'll build on top of this to convert all the code to Sequelize. (Including tests)

pullsbody:
I'm not committed to using Sequelize, so this PR is just to show how it's used as a comparison to the more manual database code currently in `db-utils.js` and `subscribers.js`. In particular `subscribers.js` is already pointed in this "model" direction anyway: i.e., providing connection plumbing and helper methods to get, add, and delete user records in the database table.

I'll make inline comments on the main "magical" bits ...

pullsbody:
Fixes #58 

Attempting to overwrite an `AppConstant.*` will now fail w/ the following:

```sh
$ npm start

> blurts-server@0.0.1 start /Users/pdehaan/dev/github/mozilla/blurts-server
> node server.js

/Users/pdehaan/dev/github/mozilla/blurts-server/server.js:13
AppConstants.PORT = 9096;
                  ^

TypeError: Cannot assign to read only property 'PORT' of object '#<Object>'
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/pdehaan/dev/github/mozilla/blurts-server/server.js:13:19)
    at Module._compile (module.js:643:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:654:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:556:32)
    ...
```

pullsbody:
This implements a database interface (for Postgres) that is up to parity with the previous Set implementation. It's still rough around the edges but it works (I quickly tested out all the features in test.html).

I want to do a self-review of this and iron out all the wrinkles, but also wanted to get this PR up asap so that y'all can take a look.

You'll need to run a Postgres server to test this out, and set env vars to tell the db code how to takl to it (see changes to .env-dist).

There's a pretty basic db-scripts.js that has a function to reset the users table as well as a quick smoke test (that currently relies on console.logs, and doesn't do any REAL testing - I'm working on it).

pull_repo_desc: Firefox Monitor arms you with tools to keep your personal information safe. Find out what hackers already know about you and learn how to stay a step ahead of them.

pullsbody:
This sets up a lot of tooling, but I found this all to be a very nice testing stack on my [`blok`](https://github.com/mozilla/blok) repository.

* `.travis.yml` to make Travis run builds
* [`tape`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/tape) as the test harness
* [`faucet`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/faucet) to pretty-print the test output
* [`nyc`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/nyc) command-line interface for [istanbul](https://www.npmjs.com/package/istanbul) JS code coverage
* [`coveralls`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/coveralls) to publish the test code coverage to coveralls.io

It adds a `test` script to `package.json` that combines all of the above in a way that produces ...

* [Travis CI report](https://travis-ci.org/mozilla/blurts-server/builds/339294486?utm_source=github_status&utm_medium=notification) 
* [Coveralls code coverage report](https://coveralls.io/builds/15446378)

... for every pull request & commit.

Make message less scary, provide useful information

breached, and instead offers a breach date and the data
which was compromised (user can now make an informed decision
on whether credential update is needed).
